The religious right says you're an "anti-Christian bigot" if you find their hate speech offensive. They argue that Matt's [shepard's] killers probably didn't read their anti-gay press releases, so it's unfair to say that their vocal bigotry led to violence.
 
 But the simple fact remains that religious extremists vilify gays on a regular basis, creating and feeding a culture that inadvertently gives comfort to those who choose to express their hate in violence. The religious right calls gays diseased, perverted, immoral, and abomination. They say on TV and radio that gays deserve to lose their jobs, their children, their families and their homes. They prepare studies for Congress "proving" gays are unfit teachers, parents, ambassadors, and soldiers. They liken gays to pedophiles, adulterers, murderers, kleptomaniacs, and alcoholics. And they accuse gays of being anti-family, anti-Christian, anti-America, and anti-God.
 
 It is simply not possible to constantly preach the inhumanity of man, then blithely skulk away when principle meets practice. It is simply not moral to give a child a gun, then feign ignorance when someone gets hurt.
 
 If words do not inspire actions, then why did the top religious right organizations spend $500,000 on an ad campaign to inspire gays to 'convert'? They know words have consequences, and their words are nothing less than the subjugation and dehumanization of gay and lesbian Americans. While most on the far-right don't preach violence, it is no wonder that decades of their disdain eventually led to murder. 
 http://www.hatecrime.org/subpages/hatespeech/hate.html

 Ok, Joe. I did the Google search you requested me to do. Here's my summary of this journey . . .
 - 1st page: On the first page, there were several hits about historical Nazi persecution of gay people in WWII. No surprise there, and no bearing on current culture of violence. So nothing really on page 1 that indicates a contribition of religion toward a culture of violence in our context.
 
 - 2nd page: Ah ha! 2 hits of possible relevance--a Salon article about churches supporting an anti-gay marriage amendment (though no comments about their feelings about gay people or calls of violence). And WorldNetDaily news article about some gay people planning harassment toward Christians. Possible 2 out of 10 links may contribute to a culture of violence (or may not). Wait, there's something about "religion" . . . oh, no that's "religioustolerence.org." Not an anti-gay site at all.
 
 - 3rd page. Pay dirt! Yes, there is one article at some site called "Etherzone.com" linked here that has some very harsh things to say about homosexual living, calling the 'sodomizers' and so forth. I have to take issue with their comments and approach. One site. 
 
 - 4th Page: There's one doc linked from something called "leaderu" that talks about how homosexuals can change. Well, maybe that would possibly fit the gay rights lobby criteria for contributing to a culture of violence. I don't know. Hey, it's a negative article to the gay rights message, right?? That we can agree on.
 
 - 5th page: Well, we're now 50 links deep in this Google excursion. One news article about the pope readying some document against gay marriage--it's not an "anti-gay website," but I guess the report could contribute to a culture of violence, maybe. Hmm. Oh, there's another WorldNetDaily article. "Judge rules against Christians who preached to homosexuals." I think that might be a blacklisted site by the gay lobby as "anti-gay", so we'll chalk it up as another definite.
 Ok, I think 5 pages of links ought to suffice as a good sampling. I went over 50 links in, and found that 2 definite anti-gay articles--yeah it could indeed contribute to a culture of violence, if there were many more to go with them. There were maybe 3 others that MAY possibly contribute to a 'culture of violence, but thety were simply reports and not anti-gay websites. 
 
 Joe, I'm sorry dude, but you were simply wrong. There are not hundreds of anti-gay sites coming up in your search. Not even 50. Not even 10. Not even 5. No links to James Dobson, or Jerry Falwell. No mention of Paul Cameron. Only 2 WorldNetDaily links. And a 'LeaderU' article (whatever that is). The other 2 or 3 mention things in passing--they aren't anti-gay websites. In fact, a lot of what I saw come up were links to pro-gay sites. It seems you all have quite a showing on Google--a lot more than anti-gay ones for sure. I took your challenge, and you were wrong. How am I supposed to assume what you are telling me is true? I remain unconvinced.

 Yes dude, there are hundred of these anti-gay christian sites......maybe you misunderstood my comment, I will rephrase it......
 
 There are hundreds of anti-gay, christian websites out there that demonize gays and lesbians.......I can list many if you would like, If I had the time to kill I would create a list....oh wait I posted a list for you and you didn't take that as evidence, I posted hatecrime.org and all their proof of demonizing, now I have posted the Southern Poverty Law Center's article as proof.
 
 
 How much freaking proof do you need or are you that blind......
 
 YOu are unconvinced because you do not want to believe in the truth.....
